questions.text: A 2-year-old child on examination shows signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of vitamin A to be administered to this child?
questions.solution:

questions.text: According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India, what is the target for the reduction of the incidence of malaria by 2024?
questions.solution:
According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016), the planned target is to reduce the incidence of malaria to less than 1 case per 1000 population per year by 2024 in all states, Union Territories, and their districts.

The Framework has four objectives:

  • Eliminate malaria from all low and moderate-transmission states/union territories (UTs) by 2022;
  • Reduce the incidence of malaria to less than 1 case per 1000 population per year in all states and UTs and their districts by 2024;
  • Interrupt indigenous transmission of malaria throughout the entire country, including all high transmission states and union territories (UTs) by 2027
  • Prevent the re-establishment of local transmission of malaria in areas where it has been eliminated and maintain national malaria-free status by 2030 and beyond.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes for advice on diet, he would like to know about foods that favor the slow release of sugar. Which among the following is considered to have a low glycemic index?
questions.solution:
Pasta foods have a low glycemic index, all the other options have high.

Glycemic index (GI) is the area under the two-hour blood glucose response curve (AUC) following the ingestion of a fixed portion of test carbohydrate as a proportion of the AUC of the standard (glucose or white bread).

This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

The classification of foods according to Glycemic index (GI) is as follows,

  • Low GI foods (GI = 55 or less): Most fruits and vegetables (except potatoes, watermelon, and sweet corn), whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
  • Moderate GI foods (GI = 56 to 69): Sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
  • High GI foods (GI = 70 or more): Corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, candies, and syrupy foods.

questions.text: According to Indian Factories Act, which of the following provisions is incorrect with respect to an adolescent working in any factory?

choices.text: Adolescents should be duly certified for fitness
The Act prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age
They can work only between 6AM and 7PM.
The work hours should be 6 hours per day

questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, adolescents should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.

Under the Factories Act, children below 14 years of age are prohibited from working.

  • Provisions of the Factories Act, for adolescents between 15 and 18 years:
    • They can work only between 6 AM and 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.
    • They are restricted from working in dangerous occupations.
    • Adolescents should be duly certified regarding their fitness for work.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the inference from the equipment’s procedure?
questions.solution:
The given apparatus is Horrock’s apparatus and development of blue color indicates free chlorine.  

Note:

Development of yellow color is seen in orthotolidine (OT) test and indicates both free and combined chlorine, i.e. total chlorine.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with chickenpox calls his family doctor and asks how long he should isolate to prevent the infection from spreading to his family. What should the physician tell him?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir
Until all the lesions are crusted

questions.solution:
The physician should tell the man that he must isolate himself from his family until all of his skin lesions are crusted. This will help to prevent the transmission of the virus to his family members. Isolation is an important method to prevent the further spread of chickenpox as the secondary attack rates in household contacts are very high (up to 90%). The individual remains infective from approximately 48 hours before the appearance of the rash, during the time of vesicle formation (4-5 days), and till the point where all the lesions have crusted over. 

Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It spreads via droplet infection during personal contact and enters through the respiratory system or the conjunctiva. The course of chickenpox can be divided into 2 stages-

  • Pre-eruptive The pre-eruptive stage includes the fever and viral prodrome, which lasts for 2-3 days until the rash begins to appear
  • The eruptive stage begins with the appearance of the rash. It usually appears first on the trunk, followed by the limbs and face. The rash quickly goes through the various stages (pleomorphism)-macule, papule, vesicle, and finally scab. The vesicle stage has classically been said to have a "dew-drop" appearance. Complications such as cerebellar ataxia, pneumonia, and encephalitis are uncommon but can be seen in some adults and immunocompromised patients. 

The usual control methods include notifying regarding a new case, isolation, and disinfection. Antiviral therapy like acyclovir can prevent systemic disease, especially in immunosuppressed patients. Exposed patients who are immunocompromised may receive the varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG), within 72 hours of exposure to a chickenpox patient. The immunoglobulin must be administered immediately as it has no effect once the disease is established. 

Other options:

Option A: Fever and malaise may subside during the eruptive (vesicle formation) stage, but the patient remains contagious at this point.

Option B: It is unnecessary to isolate until all the lesions have disappeared because the patient is not at risk of transmitting the virus once the lesions have crusted.

Option C: Acyclovir is recommended in adults and children if started within 24 hours of disease onset. However, in some patients with mild illness, conservative management is sufficient.  Regardless of the treatment taken, patients are recommended to follow the same isolation guidelines.

questions.text: You are interpreting data collected from a city to write a research paper on the extent of pollution in it. You come across the soiling index. What is it an indicator of?
questions.solution:
The soiling index or smoke index is an indicator of air pollution.

The soiling index is a measure of the total suspended particulate matter in air. A known air volume is filtered through a white filter paper, and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter. It is expressed as micrograms/ cubic meters of air over a certain period. The best indicators of air pollution include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. 

Currently, the Air Quality Index (AQI) is the most commonly used tool for the air quality status and severity of pollution. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration  to calculate the AQI -

  • PM10 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  • PM2.5 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  • NO2 (nitrogen dioxide)
  • SO2 (sulfur dioxide)
  • CO (carbon monoxide)
  • O3 (ozone)
  • NH3 (ammonia)
  • Pb (lead)

The National AQI categories and the range are as follows :

questions.text: A 20-day old baby is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go to the nearby hospital. Which national programme has provisions to benefit this woman to take her baby to the health facility?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.

Assured 18 service guarantees are provided to all pregnant women under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative to provide assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare at no cost and zero tolerance for denial of services for every woman and newborn visiting the public health facility. questions.text: The Fernandez reaction of lepromin test is read at _________
questions.solution:
The Fernandez reaction or the early reaction of the lepromin test is read at 48 hours.

Lepromin test is a prognostic test used in the classification of Leprosy. It has no diagnostic purpose.

  • It involves performing an intradermal injection of the lepromin antigen (synthesized from M. leprae) on the flexor surface of the forearm.
  • It is an indicator of cell-mediated immunity and hence may be positive in normal individuals as well. 
  • A positive test indicates good cell-mediated immunity and towards Tuberculoid side of the spectrum
  • A negative test indicates poor cell-mediated immunity and towards the Lepromatous side of the spectrum.

There are two possible responses:

  • The early reaction of Fernandez - Positive within 48-72 hours if there is the erythema measuring >10 mm
  • Late Reaction of Mitsuda - Positive at 21 days if there is the onset of a papule measuring 5 mm or more (A better indicator of Cell-Mediated Immunity)

questions.text: You are starting services for hypertension in your PHC. 50 patients who required antihypertensive treatment were transferred from another center. 40 of them were on amlodipine (5mg PO) and 10 were on lisinopril (10 mg PO) as they had contraindications to the use of amlodipine. The drugs are supplied at the PHC on a monthly basis and you have to place an order for their medications. What is the number of tablets that you will order and the reorder factor?
questions.solution:
The Quantity to Order (QO) or the reorder quantity of medicines to be placed at each order interval is calculated using the reorder formula as given below:

QO = CA x (LT + PP) = CA x Rf

where QO is the quantity to order, CA is average consumption in a month, LT is lead time, PP is procurement period and Rf is the reorder factor. Reorder factor (Rf) is the sum of lead time (LT) and procurement period (PP). Lead time (LT) is the time between the initiation of a purchase order and receipt at the warehouse from the supplier. The procurement period (PP) covers the time until the next regular order will be placed.

In the given question, lead time (LT) and procurement period (PP) are 1 month each.

Average consumption (CA) in a month = (40 tablets of amlodipine + 10 tablets of lisinopril) x 30 days = 1500 tablets

Reorder factor (Rf) = LT + PP = 1 + 1 = 2

Since these patients got transferred from another center there is no safety stock for them at present at the facility. So in order to prevent stockouts for them, an extra number of tablets must be ordered, which makes 1600 tablets with a reorder factor (Rf) of 2 the correct option.

Factors determining the reorder formula are:

  1. Average consumption or demand of the drug (CA) in a month
  2. Supplier Lead time (LT): is the time between initiation of a purchase order and receipt at the warehouse from the supplier.
  3. Safety stock (SS): is the stock that should always be on hand to prevent stockouts. The safety stock level and reorder level will be the same if consumption and lead times are predictable and stable.
  4. Procurement period (PP): it covers the time until the next regular order will be placed. In a scheduled system this is in multiples of one month and in a perpetual system, it is counted in days or weeks. Note: Quantity ordered (QO) + Safety Stock (SS) must cover the time until the next order is received, which is given by the Reorder factor (Rf) = Procurement Period (PP) + Lead Time (LT).
  5. Reorder level: is the quantity of remaining stock that should trigger a reorder of the item. In a basic purchasing formula, reorder level is calculated by multiplying the average lead time by the average consumption of the drug during the lead time.
  6. Maximum stock level: is the same as the target stock level, which is required to satisfy demand until the next order is received.
  7. Stock position: is the sum of stock on hand (working and safety stock) and stock on order, minus any stock back-ordered to clients.

questions.text: A meta-analysis is being performed to evaluate the relationship between obesity and endometrial carcinoma. Which among the following is false regarding this technique?

choices.text: File drawer effect can be seen here
It increases the statistical power  by increasing sample size
Apples and oranges effect can be seen here
Its validity does not depend on the quality of the systematic review

questions.solution:
The validity of the meta-analysis depends on the quality of the systematic review.

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

questions.text: A child was weaned off of breastmilk by 3 months of age which caused severe malnutrition and recurrent infections. This falls under which ecological factor of malnutrition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario showing early curtailment of breastfeeding causing malnutrition is one example of child-rearing practices that leads to malnutrition.

Ecology of Malnutrition :

The ecological factors related to malnutrition as follows 

  1. Conditioning influences: A conditioning factor that plays a huge role in malnutrition is infectious diseases which causes a vicious cycle where infections cause malnutrition which in turn causes minor childhood ailments. Diarrhoeal diseases, intestinal parasites, measles, whooping cough, malaria, tuberculosis contributes significantly to malnutrition. The occurrence of infections are largely based on the environmental conditions that the child is exposed to.
  2. Cultural influences: Poor diets as a result of cultural and regional influences also play a role in malnutrition. They are as follows with an example for each:
    • Food habits, traditions, customs, beliefs and attitudes: Rice and wheat are largely staple in India. Papaya is avoided as it is thought to cause abortion.
    • Religion: Hindus do not eat beef and Muslims do not eat pork.
    • Food fads: Personal likes and dislikes to a certain group of foods.
    • Cooking practices: Prolonged boiling of cereals in open pans which leads to a loss of nutritive value
    • Child-rearing practices: Premature curtailment of breastfeeding
  3. Socio-economic factors: Poverty plays a huge role in causing malnutrition. This is usually a result of ignorance, insufficient education, lack of knowledge regarding the nutritive value of foods, inadequate sanitary environment, large family size, etc. which affects the quality of life.
  4. Food production: The amount of food produced is directly proportional to the amount of food consumed. Developed countries have 5.8 hectares of arable land compared to the 0.6 hectares of land per Indian. Even distribution of food among all sectors of society is also a factor.
  5. Health and other services: Remedial actions that can be taken by the health sector to reduce malnutrition are as follows - 
    • Nutritional surveillance - Continuous monitoring of factors that affect nutrition; groups affected are identified.
    • Nutritional rehabilitation - Urgent care for individuals suffering from severe malnutrition.
    • Nutrition supplementation - Supplementary feeds for mothers and children
    • Health education - Health education programmes to increase awareness about malnutrition and nutrition value of food.

questions.text: Which of the following are transmitted biologically by invertebrate vectors?
questions.solution:
Metazoonoses are a type of zoonoses where the infective agents are transmitted by invertebrate vectors. They multiply and develop within the invertebrates (extrinsic incubation period) before transmission to a vertebrate host.

A zoonosis is any disease or infection that is naturally transmissible from vertebrate animals to humans. They can be classified based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses - transmitted from lower vertebrates to man
  • Zooanthroponoses - transmitted from man to lower vertebrates 
  • Amphixenoses - may be transmitted in either direction

They can also be classified based on the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact, fomites, mechanical vector

No developmental or propagative changes during transmission

Rabies, brucellosis, trichinosis

Cyclo-zoonoses

Require > 1 vertebrate host to complete the developmental cycle

Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors 

Infective agent develops and multiplies within the invertebrate (extrinsic incubation period) after which it is transmitted to another vertebrate host

Arboviral infections, plague and schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil, plants) developmental site or reservoir

Various forms of larva migrans and mycoses

questions.text: The first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit is called as _________
questions.solution:
A primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.

Other options:

  • An index case is the first case of the disease that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.
  • A suspect case is a case that has all the clinical features of the disease but has not been diagnosed with it.

questions.text: While working in a family planning center, you have been advising couples regarding contraceptive methods. The curious interns ask you to explain the pearl index mentioned in a learning poster in the clinic. Which of the following points related to this would be incorrect?

choices.text: It is a method to measure the contraceptive efficacy
Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions
Four months are deducted from total months of exposure for abortion
The number 1200 indicates the number of months in 100 years

questions.solution:
The option stating "Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions" is the incorrect statement.

Total accidental pregnancies include every form of conception, like live births, stillbirths, or abortions, or the pregnancy that has not yet been terminated.

Pearl index:

It is defined as the number of "failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY)." It is a method used to measure contraceptive efficacy. This rate is given by the formula - 

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure.

Other options:

Total months of exposure in the denominator is calculated after deducting 10 months for a full-term pregnancy, and 4 months for an abortion.

The number 1200 in the formula indicates the number of months in 100 years.

There is a decline in failure rates with increasing duration of use with most methods of contraception but the Pearl index is usually based on a specific exposure (usually one year) and, therefore, fails to accurately compare methods at various durations of exposure.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct with respect to disaster management?
  1. Rehabilitation is the final phase in a disaster that leads to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions.
  2. Disaster mitigation is a risk reduction measure before the occurrence of a disaster.
  3. Disaster preparedness is short-term developmental activity.
  4. The response includes triage, tagging, identification of the dead, and relief activities.
  5. Vaccination of the mass population against typhoid, cholera, and tetanus is recommended.
questions.solution:
Disaster preparedness refers to long-term development activities that strengthen the capacity of a country to effectively manage all kinds of emergencies. WHO does not recommend for the routine use of typhoid and cholera vaccines even in endemic areas.

  • Response - This includes activities such as:

          Triage: Classifying the injured based on the severity of the injuries and chances of survival with medical intervention. 

          Tagging: Tags with name, age, triage category, diagnosis and treatment are put for identification purposes. 

          Identification of the dead: The dead bodies should be shifted from the disaster site to the mortuary.

  • Rehabilitation - This includes measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.
  • Mitigation - This includes measures to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of them are flood mitigation, land use planning, improved building codes, and the reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures. 
  • Preparedness - This is a program that aims at strengthening the capacity of a country to manage all types of emergencies efficiently. Its objective is to ensure that appropriate measurements are taken for the relief and rehabilitation of disaster victims.

Some measures that should be followed by all in case of an emergency include:

  • Avoiding telephone use, unless it is to call for help
  • Listen to and carry out the radio or loudspeaker broadcast messages
  • Carry out the official instructions given over the radio or by loudspeaker
  • Keep a family emergency kit ready

Note: Vaccination of the general population post-disaster against typhoid, cholera, and tetanus is not recommended.

questions.text: A 35-year-old presents with spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Diet history reveals chronic consumption of Khesari dal before the onset of this paralysis. This condition is caused by which of the following toxic compounds?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with spastic paralysis and dietary history of consumption of Khesari dal is suggestive of lathyrism. This condition is caused by the toxic compound beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA).

Lathyrism is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. It is a paralyzing disease in humans and animals. In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system and another variant is osteolathyrism causing skeletal deformities. A proper dietary history will reveal chronic consumption of this pulse in large quantities. Neurolathyrism is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. 

The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses, by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. This method is called the steeping method. Parboiling can be done in large-scale operations. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

Note- Aflatoxin is a metabolite produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus. Aflatoxin toxicity presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, convulsions, and signs of acute liver injury. Long-term exposure can result in growth retardation, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms develop after consumption of mustard oil contaminated with argemone oil?

choices.text: Non-inflammatory, bilateral pitting edema with diarrhoea
Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs

questions.solution:
Argemone oil contains a toxic alkaloid sanguinarine which causes epidemic dropsy. Symptoms include non-inflammatory, bilateral pitting edema associated with diarrhea. 

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure. Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

Other options -

Option B: Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, and peripheral gangrene are caused by the consumption of ergot-infested grain leading to ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus.  Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Option C: Rapidly developing ascites and jaundice are associated with the consumption of millets contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia which contain a toxic pyrrolizidine alkaloid and produce symptoms of endemic ascites that manifest as rapidly developing ascites and jaundice. 

Option D: Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs is associated with the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus leading to neurolathyrism. 

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

The appropriate method of treatment of the intraosseous needle, shown in the image, is autoclaving.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutters or burners, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause punctures and cuts are disposed of in white, translucent, puncture-proof, and leak-proof containers. They are treated by autoclaving/ dry heat sterilization followed by - shredding/mutilation/encapsulation and later sent to iron foundries/sanitary landfills.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

The image given below shows an autoclave.

The biomedical waste management rule applies to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose, and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorized and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then treated by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration (Option B)- this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection (Option D)- chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes.

questions.text: An observer notes that the maternal deaths that happened in hospital deliveries in the past year are higher than maternal deaths in home deliveries. He comes to the conclusion that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals. This is an example of :
questions.solution:
This is an example of spurious association. This is an association that appears due to improper comparison. It may lead to a spurious association or an association when none actually existed.

Here, maternal mortality is likely to have been higher in hospital deliveries compared to home deliveries because hospitals attract women at high risk for delivery because of their special equipment and expertise, whereas this is not necessarily the case with home deliveries. When confounding factors and selection biases are not accounted for, it may result in incorrect conclusions regarding the association. So the conclusion that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals is likely to have been spurious or artifactual.

Association can be broadly grouped under three headings:

  • Spurious association
  • Indirect association
  • Direct (causal) association
    • One-to-one causal association
    • Multifactorial causation

Option A: Direct (causal) association- Two variables are stated to be causally related (AB) if a change in A is followed by a change in B. When factor A is present, disease B must result. Measles is one such disease in which such a relation exists.

Option B: Indirect association- The indirect association is an association between a  variable and disease due to the presence of another factor, known or unknown, that is also known as the "confounding" variable. For example, endemic goiter is generally found in high altitudes, showing thereby an association between altitude and endemic goiter. But, endemic goiter is not due to altitude but due to environmental deficiency of iodine. Thus, a common factor (i.e., iodine deficiency) can result in an apparent association between two variables, when no association exists. 

Option D: Multifactorial causation is seen in non-communicable diseases or conditions (e.g., Coronary heart disease) where the etiology is multifactorial.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with an unprovoked Category-III dog bite. He was not immunized previously. After washing the wound, and vaccination, you have decided to give immunoglobulin. Your hospital provides equine rabies immunoglobulin. The maximum dose that can be given is ______
questions.solution:
The maximum dosage of equine rabies immunoglobulin that can be given is 40 IU/kg body weight.

Rabies immunoglobulin is provided in 2 types and their doses should be:

  • Human rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG): 20 IU/kg body weight.
  • Equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG): 40 IU/kg body weight.

Rabies immunoglobulin is administered only once at or as soon as possible after the initiation of post-exposure vaccination. Beyond the seventh day after the first dose of vaccine, rabies immunoglobulin is not indicated because an active antibody response to the vaccine has already occurred.

The use of monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus as alternatives for RIGs in PEP is under study.

Management of category III bite:

A category III wound is single or multiple transdermal bites, scratches, or licks on broken skin. It includes contamination of mucous membrane with saliva from licks or contacts with bats. 

  • In previously unimmunized patients, Immediate vaccination and rabies immunoglobulin administration is needed with local wound treatment. 
  • The wound and adjoining area should be cleaned with plenty of soap and water, preferably under running water for at least 15 minutes to minimize the risk of contracting rabies. 
  • After cleaning, the wound should be treated with virucidal agents like alcohol or tincture iodine.
  • If the wound needs suturing, it should be done 24-48 hours after the incident with minimum sutures. Immediate suturing may spread the virus into deeper tissues. 

Post-exposure prophylaxis in previously unimmunized patients

  • Essen regimen:
    • 5 dose regimen: One intramuscular dose each on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 days 
  • Zareb regimen:
    • 4 dose multisite regimen, 2 intramuscular doses on day 0, and 1 intramuscular dose each on days 7 and 21 
  • Intradermal regimen:
    • 2 site regimen, two intradermal doses on days 0, 3, 7, and 28. 

Zero by 30 : is the Global strategic plan to end human death from dog mediated rabies by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about district and sub-district hospitals?

choices.text: All districts need at least two district hospitals.
The minimum essential number of beds in a sub-district hospital is 100.
All districts do not need a sub-district hospital.
DNB training can be done in district hospitals.

questions.solution:
Every district should have at least one comprehensively functioning district hospital (DH).

District hospitals and subdistrict hospitals provide secondary care health services. Every district should have at least one comprehensively functioning DH. Districts with a population of less than 5 lakhs and with a functional DH do not need a subdistrict hospital (SDH). Districts with a population of 5–10 lakhs can have one SDH. For a population of more than 10 lakhs, 1 SDH is needed for every 10 lakh population.

The three pillars of district hospital services are providing clinical care, providing a knowledge hub for capacity development, and public health programs.

Important functions of DHs:

  • Providing curative services
  • Palliative and rehabilitative services
  • Implementation of health programs
  • Drugs and diagnostic services
  • Administrative and other support services
  • Health promotion and prevention, education
  • Providing educational services, like Diplomate of National Board (DNB) training; training courses for healthcare professionals (HCPs) in auxiliary nursing and midwifery (ANM), telemedicine, and technology; and partnerships with universities

questions.text: What type of study is shown below?
questions.solution:
The study shown is a prospective cohort study. 

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. It can be divided into:

  • Prospective cohort studies: Outcome has not occurred at the time of the beginning of the investigation 
  • Retrospective cohort studies: Outcome has occurred before the beginning of the investigation 
  • Combination cohort studies: Both retrospective and prospective elements are combined

A cohort is a group of individuals who share a common experience or characteristic within a defined time period. The cohort groups are selected before the appearance of the disease under investigation. They are divided into study and control cohorts. The study cohorts are exposed to a particular factor thought to be related to the disease occurrence whereas the control cohorts are not exposed to this particular factor.  

Studying the effects of exposure to uranium in causing lung cancer is an example of a cohort study. Uranium miners are taken as the study cohort and other individuals who are not exposed to uranium mining are taken as the control cohort. 

Note: In a nested case-control study, cases of disease that have occurred in a defined cohort are identified. A specified number of matched controls who have not developed the disease are then selected from the cohort. 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.

questions.text: Which of the following indices is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake?
questions.solution:
Net protein utilization (NPU) is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake.

NPU is calculated as the percentage of protein retained by the body from the total protein intake. It is described as the product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value multiplied by 100.

1 gram of protein is equivalent to 6.25 g of nitrogen. The NPU value of a dietary protein and the protein requirement of the individual are inversely related to each other. The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Other options:

Option A: Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the ratio of milligrams of digestible dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the dietary protein to the milligrams of the same dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the reference protein. 

Option C: The biological value is calculated as the amount of nitrogen used for tissue formation divided by the nitrogen absorbed from food expressed in percentage. It is a reflection of essential amino acid supplied and a measure of protein quality. 

Option D: The amino acid score refers to the concentration of each essential amino acid in the test protein. It is calculated as the percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

questions.text: In which of the following time periods during the course of a disease would it be beneficial to administer a screening test to a patient?
questions.solution:
The time difference between the first possible point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis is called screening time, which is represented by the time interval 1 to 2 in the given image. It is during this time period in course of the disease, it would be beneficial to administer a screening test to a patient.

Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

The usual time of diagnosis (point 3): The onset of symptoms is followed by a short interval (varies from disease to disease) after which the patient presents to a healthcare setup, where a diagnosis of the disease is made. Based on treatment and prognosis, the patient can progress to either recovery, disability, or death. 

In the image, the period between the first possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis is called lead time and is represented by the time period between points 1 and 3 in the image. Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Natural history of disease: It refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment.

Exposure: The disease process begins with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host. For example in infectious disease, the exposure is a microorganism. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibers or components in tobacco smoke.

Pathological changes: After the disease process has been triggered, pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it. This stage of subclinical disease, extending from the time of exposure to the onset of symptoms, is usually called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases. During this stage, the disease remains asymptomatic.

The onset of clinical symptoms: It is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.

questions.text: In a population of 500 people selected at random, systolic blood pressure is normally distributed with a mean of 120mmHg and a standard deviation of 10mmHg. How many people would be expected to have systolic blood pressure between 110 and 120mmHg?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, with a normal distribution graph with a mean SBP of 120 mmHg and a standard deviation of 10mmHg, 170 individuals will have an SBP between 110 and 120mmHg. 

In a normal distribution curve:

  • 68% of the sample population lie between mean ± 1 SD.
  • 95.5% of the sample population lie between mean ± 2 SD
  • 99.7% of the sample population lie between mean ± 3 SD

So the number of individuals having their SBP between 110 and 120mmHg can be calculated as follows:

  • People with SBP between 110 and 120mmHg clearly belong to one half of the 68% confidence interval of the above distribution, which is given by, mean ± 1 SD,

        i.e, 68% CI = 120 ± 1 x 10

                          = 110 to 130mmHg

  • Therefore, 34% of the total population belongs to 110 - 120 SBP distribution, i.e, 34% of 500

                   = 170



Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text:
In India, any of the following should be considered as evidence of an outbreak of polio except:

WPV: Wild Polio Virus

VDPV: Vaccine Derived Polio Virus.

cVDPV: circulating Vaccine Derived Polio Virus.

choices.text: Detection of VDPV in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of a single case of WPV in a person with Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of any cVDPV infected individuals
Detection of WPV infection in a healthy asymptomatic individual

questions.solution:
Detection of VDPV (Vaccine Derived Paralytic Polio) in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) would be categorized as a polio event, and not as a polio outbreak. 

In India, where polio is not endemic, and has been eradicated, polio outbreak is defined based on the following specific evidence of transmission:

Human Detection of:

  • any WPV-infected individual(s) manifesting either as a case of AFP or even if asymptomatic and healthy (without documented exposure to WPV in a laboratory or vaccine production facility)
  • any cVDPV-infected individual(s)

Environmental Detection of:

  • 2 or more separate environmental samples positive for WPV with genetic sequencing information indicating sustained local transmission
  • A single environmental sample positive for WPV with follow-up evidence of virus excretion (and no documented exposure in a laboratory or vaccine production facility); OR
  • Any cVDPV positive environmental sample(s)

 

Polio Events have no evidence of polio transmission and are defined as

 

Human Detection of:

  • VDPV in: - single acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) case or asymptomatic person (e.g. contact), or - one or more persons, with no evidence of further community-level circulation (iVDPV or aVDPV isolates)
  • Type 2 Sabin or Sabin-like isolate from individual sample(s) more than four months after use of any type 2 containing OPV (i.e. mOPV2 or tOPV)
  • WPV1, WPV2, or WPV3 infected individual with suspected or documented type-specific virus exposure in a laboratory or vaccine production facility.

Environmental Detection of: 

  • WPV single environmental sample without follow-up evidence of virus excretion;
  • VDPV without evidence of further transmission, such as: - a single environmental sample without evidence of prolonged circulation; or - an aVDPV.
  • Type 2 Sabin or Sabin-like isolate from environmental sample(s) more than four months after use of any type 2 containing OPV (i.e. mOPV2 or tOPV).

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby at the primary health center. While examining the baby, you notice a foot deformity as shown in the image below. Screening for other defects and early cost-free intervention for this condition is covered under which of the following schemes?
questions.solution:
The condition seen in the given image is clubfoot (congenital talipes equinovarus or CTEV). Screening of this birth defect and early intervention are covered under the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram scheme.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an important initiative aiming at early identification and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years to cover 4 ‘D’s which are:

  • Defects at birth
  • Deficiencies
  • Diseases
  • Development delays, including disability.

The first level of screening is done by medical officers, staff nurses, and ANMs, at all the places where deliveries are conducted. After 48 hours, up to 6 weeks, the screening of newborns will be done by ASHA at home as a part of the Home Based New-born Care (HBNC) package.

The target groups are divided into three groups based on age:

  • Newborn to 6 weeks
  • 6 weeks to 6 years
  • 6 years to 18 years.

They screen all the babies born at public health facilities and at home, preschool children in rural areas and urban slums, and children up to 12th grade enrolled in government schools.

Defects screened during birth :

  • Neural tube defect 
  • Down's Syndrome 
  • Cleft Lip & Palate / Cleft palate alone
  • Talipes (club foot)
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital deafness
  • Congenital heart diseases
  • Retinopathy of Prematurity

Other options :

Option B: Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: NSSK is a program aimed to train health personnel in basic newborn care and resuscitation, has been launched to address care at birth issues i.e. prevention of hypothermia, prevention of infection, early initiation of breastfeeding, and basic newborn resuscitation.

Option C: Janani Sishu Suraksha Karyakaram: It is an initiative to provide completely free and cashless services to pregnant women including normal deliveries and cesarean operations and sick newborns (up to 30 days after birth) in Government health institutions in both rural & urban areas.

Option D: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This program aims to provide assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to all pregnant women on the 9th of every month.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the operations of the midday meal programme?

choices.text: Supplements 1/3rd of protein and 1/2 of calorie requirements
The mid-day meal is not a substitute for home meal
The menu should remain constant to ensure adequate nutrition
It is not a part of the Minimum Needs Programme

questions.solution:
The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets.

Under the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) programme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at least ½ of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of total daily energy requirement to children in schools.

The Midday meal scheme is also called School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme.

Principles of the MDM are:

  • The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets.
  • The cost of meals should be reasonably low.
  • The meal should be easy to cook in schools.
  • Locally available foods must be used, for as far as possible.
  • The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

questions.text: The device shown below is the most widely used instrument for measuring  _______.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a dry and wet bulb hygrometer. It is the most widely used instrument for measuring the humidity of air. 

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer consists of two identical thermometers—a dry bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer—mounted side by side on a stand. 

After obtaining the readings of both thermometers, the corresponding relative humidity can be found in psychrometric charts and slides. 

Other instruments used to measure humidity:

  • Sling psychrometer
  • Assmann psychrometer

Other options:

Option B - The mean radiant temperature is measured using a globe thermometer.

Option C - The cooling power of air was originally measured using a kata thermometer. Kata thermometer is now largely used for recording low air velocities. 

Option D - The maximum temperature reached in a given time is measured by a maximum thermometer. The thermometer is set each time by swinging briskly.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He gives influenza pandemics as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Influenza pandemics are an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years.  Examples of the cyclic trend include influenza and rubella. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to defend communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is another type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite. Some epidemiologists consider this a form of cyclic trend.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

questions.text: The government uses the following sign at public places in order to directly or indirectly alter human behavior. This is an example of which of the following approaches towards health education?
questions.solution:
The "No smoking" sign is an example of a regulatory approach.

A regulatory approach with respect to health education is defined as a government intervention, which is designed to alter human behavior either directly or indirectly. Regulations may take many forms, from prohibition to imprisonment.

Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve areas related to personal choices as well like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

The four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach

The service approach (option B) is a government intervention aimed at providing all the health services needed by the people at their doorstep so the people would use them to improve their own health. An example of this approach is the free-of-cost latrines provided by the government. But many people in the rural areas did not make use of this because its need was not felt.

The health education approach (option A) is an intervention to provide necessary behavioral changes in people to make their own choice for a healthy life through health education. Examples of this approach are cessation of smoking, use of safe water supply, fertility control through health education. 

The primary health care approach (option D) is an intervention with active involvement from the people in the planning and delivery of health services based on the principle of primary health care. This actually deals with community involvement and intersectoral coordination.

questions.text: In a study, group A received placebo while group B received a new drug. In group A,  36 deaths were reported out of a sample of 120. In group B, 26 deaths were reported out of a sample size of 130. How many patients should be treated to avert 1 death?
questions.solution:
10 patients need to be treated with the new drug to avert 1 death.
 
The number needed to treat (NNT) is defined as the number of individuals to be treated with the new drug to prevent 1 death (or to save 1 life).
 
NNT = 100/ARR
 
Where, ARR is the absolute risk reduction, which is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo group and drug group. The absolute risk is usually expressed in percentage.
 
ARR = (No. of deaths/Sample population) x 100
 
Calculation:
 
Step 1: Calculation of absolute risk rate
 
The absolute risk rate in group A (placebo)
= (36/120)x100
= 30%
 
The absolute risk rate in group B (new drug)
= (26/130)x100
= 20%
 
Step 2: Calculation of absolute risk reduction (ARR)
 
ARR = Absolute risk rate in group A - Absolute risk rate in group B
= 30 - 20
= 10%
 
Step 3: Calculation of number needed to treat
 
NNT = 100/ARR
= 100/10
= 10
 
Therefore, 10 individuals need to be treated with the new drug to save 1 life.

questions.text:
A patient admitted for hemoptysis experienced a bout of coughing, during which his blood-stained secretions came in contact with the nurse's eyes. On further probing, the patient revealed that he had been on antiretroviral therapy for 1 year. Identify the incorrect statements about post-exposure prophylaxis in this case.
  1. Two drug regime is followed since exposure is mild
  2. It should be certainly started within 72 hours of exposure
  3. It should be continued for 28 days
  4. She should undergo a test for HIV up till 6 weeks post-exposure
  5. Blood donation is allowed once PEP is completed
questions.solution:
1, 4 and 5 are the incorrect statements.

Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV should be initiated as early as possible, to all individuals with exposure ideally within 2 hours (but certainly within the first 72 hours) of exposure.

Exposures that may warrant occupational PEP include:

Parenteral or mucous membrane exposure (splashes to the eye, nose, or oral cavity. The following bodily fluids may pose a risk of HIV infection: blood, blood-stained saliva, breast milk, genital secretions, and cerebrospinal, amniotic, rectal, peritoneal, synovial, pericardial, or pleural fluids.

Exposures that do not require PEP include:

  • When the exposed individual is already HIV-positive
  • When the source is established to be HIV-negative
  • Exposure to bodily fluids that do not pose a significant risk: tears, non-blood-stained saliva, urine, and sweat.

3 drug PEP regimen is given irrespective of percutaneous or mucous membrane exposure and irrespective of mild, moderate or severe exposure. It is as follows:

        Drug combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. When available, ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis.

Follow up: HIV antibody testing should be done for at least 6 months post-exposure (e.g. at baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months) to ensure no transmission has occurred. Blood donation should be avoided while the individual is taking PEP, and while still in the window period for HIV acquisition and testing.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with complaints of persistent fever, and cough for 3 weeks. The child's mother is a known case of tuberculosis and is on treatment. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme guidelines, what should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the child is exposed to tuberculosis and has symptoms suggestive of tuberculosis. Therefore the next step in management is to do sputum CBNAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is the investigation of choice.

Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) provides an accurate and rapid diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Rifampicin (Rif) resistance-conferring mutations, in sputum specimens as well as a specimen from extra-pulmonary sites. CBNAAT is recommended for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB preferentially in the key population such as children, PLHIV, Extra-pulmonary TB, and in smear-negative TB as per the diagnostic algorithm. 

Sputum smear microscopy(Option C) is done if CBNAAT facilities are not available. Chest X-ray (Option B) and Mantoux test or tuberculin skin test (Option D) are done if MTB is not detected or sputum is not available.
