questions.text: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the programme whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except:

choices.text: Two rounds of spraying with DDT should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) should be provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index ≥ 5.
Indoor Residual Sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.
In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.

questions.solution:
Under the Integrated vector management initiative, Indoor Residual Sprays are the main method of vector control in rural areas. 

National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya. 

 

Integrated Vector Management:

  • For adult mosquitoes:
    • Indoor residual Sprays are used. It is the main method of vector control in rural areas.
    • DDT is the insecticide of choice.
    • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT and in DDT resistant areas, three rounds of spraying are done with Malathion (if DDT resistant).
  • For the larvae: Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.
  • For personal protection: 
    • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥ 2.
    • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API ≥ 5.

 

The Drug distribution centres only dispense the anti malarial drugs under the NVBDCP for Malaria. 

Important points about the organisation for the anti Malaria programme:

  • Central Government: Supplies DDT and larvicides.
  • State government: Procures the Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) for the districts.
  • District Malaria Office: Key unit for the implementation of the programme.
  • District Malaria Officer: Has direct responsibility of IRS spraying operations and is assisted by one Assistant Malaria Officer and Malaria Inspectors. 
  • Medical officer of the PHC:  Has the overall responsibility for the surveillance and laboratory services.
  • Multi Purpose Workers and ASHAs: Carry out surveillance and case detection in community.
  • Drug Distribution Centres: Only dispensing the antimalarial drugs.
  • Fever Treatment Depots: Dispense the anti malarial drugs and collect the blood slides.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: Rideal-Walker co-efficient is employed for the assessment of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Rideal-Walker coefficient helps in assessing the power of a disinfectant relative to phenol.

It assesses this by determining the phenol coefficient (PC). A PC value of > 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. Traditional organisms used to test the power of the disinfectant include S. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi.

Phenol coefficient = The dilution of test disinfectant which kills microorganisms in a given time ÷ The dilution of phenol which kills the microorganism in the same time under identical conditions.

Other tests that are used for disinfectants are as follows:

  • Chick Martin test - modification of the Rideal-Walker test where disinfectants act in the presence of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions
  • Kelsey-Skyes test (capacity test) - tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when used repeatedly.
  • In-use test - determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use

Joseph Lister first introduced phenol (carbolic acid) as an antiseptic to sterilize surgical instruments and  clean wounds. Lister's work led to a reduction in postoperative infections and made surgery safer for patients, distinguishing him as the 'Father of Modern Surgery' and 'Father of Antiseptic Surgery'.

questions.text: A newborn was visited by the ASHA worker of the community under the Home Based Neonatal Care until the baby was 42 days old. A total of how many visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home Based Care for Young Child?
questions.solution:
A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).

ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months. They will help promote early initiation of breastfeeding, exclusive breastfeeding till 6 months, and continued breastfeeding till 2nd year of life along with adequate complementary feeding and to ensure age-appropriate immunization and early childhood development.

ASHAs will be provided an additional incentive of Rs. 250 for completion of 5 home visits under HBYC for each young child (Rs. 50 per visit). HBYC is being rolled out in a phased manner. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding MMUs (Mobile Medical Units)?
  1. Lab investigations like hemoglobin estimation and pregnancy testing are available.
  2. Distribution of essential drugs is done from MMU.
  3. One MMU is approved for a district with a population of 5 lakhs.
  4. IEC (Information, education, and communication) sessions are conducted by MMUs.
  5. MMUs cover remote urban areas as well.
questions.solution:
The true statements about MMUs are 1, 2, 4, and 5.

Statement 3 is false- According to the current guidelines, 1 MMU is approved for a district with a population of 10 lakhs, and not 5 lakhs. This limit can be relaxed in tribal and hilly regions that are more inaccessible.

Mobile Medical Units (MMU) is a major initiative under NRHM to provide a range of healthcare services for people living in remote, inaccessible, un-served, and underserved areas in both rural as well as urban areas, with the aim of taking healthcare services to the doorsteps of such people.

The staff of MMUs includes:

  • Medical officer (MBBS only, preferably women): 1
  • GNM (General nursing and midwifery): 1
  • Lab Technician: 1
  • Pharmacist cum Administrative Assistant: 1
  • Driver cum Support Staff: 1

Clinical services are provided by a medical officer and team, whereas mobilization and outreach services are provided by ANMs and ASHA.

MMUs provide primary care services for common diseases (communicable and non-communicable), RCH services, screening tests, and referral to higher facilities and specialists as required. These include:

  • Provide point-of-care diagnostics: Blood glucose, pregnancy testing, urine microscopy, albumin and sugar, Hb, vision testing, and RDT for Malaria.
  • Collect sputum samples.
  • Screen populations over 35 for hypertension, diabetes, and cancers annually.
  • Undertake follow-up checks during the monthly visit and provide patients requiring drugs with a monthly supply (hypertension, diabetes, epilepsy)
  • Undertake IEC sessions on a range of health topics:
    • Improved preventive and promotive behaviors for maternal and child health, communicable diseases, including vector-borne diseases
    • Educate the community on lifestyle changes, the need for screening for NCDs, and early recognition and appropriate referral.

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

  1. Government-operated MMU
  2. Operation outsourcing to an external agency. However, capital expenditure, drugs, and supplies are provided by the Government.
  3. Both capital expenditure and operational expenditure are outsourced to an external agency. However, drugs and supplies are to be provided by the Government.

questions.text: An association between ordinal position on one ranking and ordinal position on another ranking can be determined by which of the following techniques?
questions.solution:
Spearman's rank-order correlation is used to determine the association between ordinal position on one ranking and ordinal position on another ranking.

It is one of the two most commonly used correlation coefficients. It is used for ordinal scale data. The other one is Pearson product-moment correlation, which is used for interval or ratio scale data.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test, and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed, but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increase.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is<5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

A paired t-test compares paired data, or pre-intervention and post-intervention data, of the same group.

The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means), and here, the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.
